Award.AwardTitle: Generation of Macroscopic Optical Polarization Bell States in Atomic Ensembles via Four-Wave Mixing
Award.AbstractNarration:
The generation and applications of entangled optical quantum states (i.e. the optical fields displaying correlations beyond those allowed by classical physics) is one of the recently recognized challenges in quantum optics. The intellectual merit of this project is to demonstrate a new approach for generation of a complete set of special fundamental non-classical states of an optical field, called Bell states, in which polarizations of two optical fields with close frequencies become quantum-mechanically entangled. Such Bell states are produced via nonlinear interaction of resonant light with Rubidium vapor. They form a natural basis for characterization and manipulation of quantum entanglement, and thus the findings will stimulate new developments in practical realizations of both quantum information protocols and in quantum-enhanced optical sensors. They will also be potentially transferrable to many other coherent systems (atomic/ionic, solid-state and photonic), with warm rubidium vapor serving as a prototype interaction.

This project offers a rich spectrum of educational opportunities by engaging graduate and undergraduate students in meaningful scientific research. Particular emphasis will be placed in attracting female and minority students, with the PI serving as a mentor and as a role model. Added educational benefits arise from adapting components of the experiments for advanced laboratory classes, and development of exciting demonstrations and public events for broader community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Lasers became a ubiquitous tool for any precision measurement, from time and length to chemicals’ concentration and living cell motion. And while such measurements are reaching unprecedented accuracy, the quantum mechanical nature of light sets a limit on how precisely we can measure changes in intensity or phase of an optical field. The goal of this project was to develop new methods for generation a light with specially tailored quantum mechanical properties that would allow to break this limit and conduct measurements with better precision compare to ones using a classical laser light. Our proposed method is based on non-degenerate four-wave mixing in Rubidium vapor using double-Lambda configuration, at which a strong optical field result in generation of entangled pair of photons, separated from it in frequency by the hyperfine splitting of the atomic ground state. Such process produces two optical fields in which the quantum fluctuations of intensities are correlated, so that one can be used as a reference of another, effectively suppressing the common-mode quantum noise below the limit set by two independent lasers. Such correlated two-optical fields are called two-mode intensity squeezed, as their mutual intensity noise can be “squeezed out” by proper differential measurements. In our experiment we were able to achieve up to 6dB of such intensity squeezing, corresponding to quantum noise suppression by a factor of 4.

We have investigated the behavior of such quantum-correlated optical fields in case of input strong pump laser and weak probe laser having phase singularities, called topological charge (i.e., when the phase of the electromagnetic fields varied azimuthally by integer of 2 pi). Such “donut beams” are widely used for optical imaging, quantum information transfer and many other areas of optics. We found that it is possible to generate two quantum correlated fields in the state with very different topological charges (we observed difference up to 6 units) and still preserve quantum intensity correlations, despite large effective size difference between the two beams after their generation.

We also demonstrated a new version of special nonlinear interferometer, called truncated SU(1,1) interferometer, in which the four-wave mixing process plays the role of a nonlinear beam-splitter. Since no additional fields enter the system, the phase measurements can be conducted with smaller quantum uncertainty, ultimately reaching the Heisenberg limit. We proposed and demonstrated the way of adjusting the phases of optical fields inside such interferometer using exclusively optical methods, to obtain desired combination of optical fields at the output to ensure minimum mutual intensity noise measurements. This method eliminates the need for multiple optical balanced detectors, and significantly increases the stability of the source.

The developed techniques will be directly applied for the development of quantum-enhanced sensor technologies, including improved optical magnetometers and gradiometer, as well as for quantum imaging of weakly absorbing objects.

Another broad impact of this project is training of students. Total of two graduate students (including one female/latina) and twelve undergraduate students (including six females) were involved in this project, and thus received extensive training in optics, electronics and quantum mechanics. Many have continued their studies in graduate programs in US, and others found employment in private sector. Thus, this project served as an effective tool for preparation of the work force for recently announced quantum initiative.
